title: fa.functional analysis - The limit of the operator norm in a Hilbert space
body: I am not familiar with functional analysis. Could you tell me please, how to prove the following statement (if it is true)? $$ \lim_\limits{M \to \infty} \|T_A - T_b \| = 0, $$ here operator norm defined as $\|A\| = \sup_\limits{\| x \| = 1}\| Ax \|$ , $x \in \ell^2$ . $T_A$ and $T_B$ are operators defined as $$ T_A = \exp\{\alpha B\}, $$ $$ T_B = \left(E - \frac{\alpha}{M}B \right)^{-(M - p)}, $$ here $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$ , $M \in \mathbb{N}$ , $p \in \mathbb{N}$ , and $B$ is the following linear operator $$ B = \sum_{k} |k\rangle \langle k+1|. $$ fa.functional-analysis operator-theory hilbert-spaces limits-and-convergence Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jun 23, 2020 at 20:00 MightyPower 335 1 1 silver badge 10 10 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 $\begingroup$ Is $E$ the identity operator? $\endgroup$ Nate Eldredge –  Nate Eldredge 2020-06-23 20:10:35 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 20:10 $\begingroup$ @Nate Eldredge, Yes E - identity operator. $\endgroup$ MightyPower –  MightyPower 2020-06-23 20:27:59 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 20:27 $\begingroup$ @Nate Eldredge, Why? I compare this with a similar limit for functions and $\lim_\limits{n \to \infty} \left(1 - \frac{a}{n} \right)^{- (n-p)} = e^a$, not $e^{pa}$. $\endgroup$ MightyPower –  MightyPower 2020-06-23 20:30:26 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 20:30 $\begingroup$ Oh you're right, never mind. $\endgroup$ Nate Eldredge –  Nate Eldredge 2020-06-23 20:32:53 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 20:32 1 $\begingroup$ This should have the same proof as the scalar calculus identity that you mention since all the operators involved here ($1,B$) commute, so the fact that we're dealing with operators rather than numbers can't really make itself felt. $\endgroup$ Christian Remling –  Christian Remling 2020-06-23 21:46:57 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 21:46 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
